text:
+1 for ClickUp, and glad to see some other ClickUp enthusiasts here like <@U015HDJ8V9A> :grinning:

their distinctive advantage is the generosity of their free plan (sooo many features that are paid in other tools are free in CU) and the speed with which they respond to user feedback and add new features.

I highly recommend joining their Facebook group, it's a great way to get a sneak peek at upcoming features.

text: Has anybody had much success updating and auditing Medium content? I update everything _when I need to_ but haven't got a set schedule. There's not a great deal you can do behind the scenes (shout if I'm wrong here) but we get 5k+ views per month and I'm wondering if we can improve this?

text: I highly recommend Infinity. In my experience, it’s like Trello and Airtable, but much more flexible than either. And I think it’s less expensive than both. (I haven’t checked recently.)

elements.text: I highly recommend Infinity. In my experience, it’s like Trello and Airtable, but much more flexible than either. And I think it’s less expensive than both. (I haven’t checked recently.)

text: I agree with <@U0162CX5SH1>. Above all, don’t charge by the hour. Quote by project. If they’re disorganized, pad your pricing so their delays and waffling don’t cost you.

elements.text: I agree with
. Above all, don’t charge by the hour. Quote by project. If they’re disorganized, pad your pricing so their delays and waffling don’t cost you.

text: Also build in a project kill or postponement fee of 50% of the project fee. It could be higher if they kill or delay it after you’ve done half the work. This is because former employers tend to think you’re at their beck and call. Your time is perishable. If they don’t use it when they’ve booked it, you can’t sell it to someone else.

elements.text: Also build in a project kill or postponement fee of 50% of the project fee. It could be higher if they kill or delay it after you’ve done half the work. This is because former employers tend to think you’re at their beck and call. Your time is perishable. If they don’t use it when they’ve booked it, you can’t sell it to someone else.

text: Yes, <@UUXMC3ZFH>. Forgot about the kill fee. My former employer is the only client (out of about 12) who has dropped a project all year.

elements.text: Yes,

text:
Sorry for the delay in response on this <@U016CGRMRAR>! The structure of the content strategy I've overseen or contributed to has varied on the last couple of positions I've had (I worked for a global, Fortune 500 company, and now I work at a mid-size company of about 150 people), but here's a type of "flow" based on my current content strategy:
• Marketing Leadership Team (MLT) meets with C-Suite to discuss overall business objectives for the year
• MLT meets with me and a few others to review business objectives, product roadmaps, big events, etc. for the year
• I develop branding/storytelling intiatives that align with the above and organize them (roughly) by quarter
• After branding themes are agreed upon by MLT, we start planning campaigns to support these branding themes and business goals per quarter (also takes into account events and product launches we want to drive leads/traffic towards)
• ^We try and do in-depth campaign planning a quarter at a time. So we would start planning campaign details for the following 3 months
• For the rest of the year, we don't do campaign planning that far in advance, but we do schedule a few key content pieces, mostly 2 big reports we publish every year and make sure those are scheduled.
• We did this exercise at the beginning of the year, and we revisit the campaign plan weekly, and the overall branding plan once-a-month and make any changes and respond to business needs. 
I hope this is helpful! I implemented this content plan for the first time at the beginning of this year, and it was working-ish. But we did hire a new CMO a few months ago, and he's switched up the approach a little bit. So elements of this strategy have remained the same, but he's added a couple of new elements. If you have any other questions, please feel free to DM me.

MLT meets with me and a few others to review business objectives, product roadmaps, big events, etc. for the year
I develop branding/storytelling intiatives that align with the above and organize them (roughly) by quarter

After branding themes are agreed upon by MLT, we start planning campaigns to support these branding themes and business goals per quarter (also takes into account events and product launches we want to drive leads/traffic towards)
^We try and do in-depth campaign planning a quarter at a time. So we would start planning campaign details for the following 3 months
For the rest of the year, we don't do campaign planning that far in advance, but we do schedule a few key content pieces, mostly 2 big reports we publish every year and make sure those are scheduled.
We did this exercise at the beginning of the year, and we revisit the campaign plan weekly, and the overall branding plan once-a-month and make any changes and respond to business needs.

I hope this is helpful! I implemented this content plan for the first time at the beginning of this year, and it was working-ish. But we did hire a new CMO a few months ago, and he's switched up the approach a little bit. So elements of this strategy have remained the same, but he's added a couple of new elements. If you have any other questions, please feel free to DM me.

text: As someone who works in SEO first then content strategy second, I'm often in two minds about courses online that are often either too much about content neglecting SEO and having a full blown SEO course being too light on human centered content. I've done Andy's course on CXL and found it too light SEO wise and heavy on promotion, and in my experience often technical seo is so underrated and neglected by folks in the content space. Wonder what you guys think. <@UUXMCJQ15> wonder if I could PM you on the course you've mentioned?

text: <@U0153M0K2N7> please do!

elements.text: please do!

text:
It's true there's not much you can do behind the scenes except for always adding a subtitle, a kicker, image meta data, and a footer that links to your other articles.

What I've learned is:
• Guest writers for your pub are the fastest way to gain followers
• Claps and responses are everything
• You're at the mercy of Medium featuring and prioritizing your story
• If you're publishing the same post on your site and Medium, have different titles because you can use a boxing out SEO strategy and have two chances for a reader to click on your article
Other than that, you optimize for Google SEO the same way you would on-site content—except it'll probably perform better because Medium has a higher domain rating.

elements.text:
It's true there's not much you can do behind the scenes except for always adding a subtitle, a kicker, image meta data, and a footer that links to your other articles.

What I've learned is:
Guest writers for your pub are the fastest way to gain followers
Claps and responses are everything
You're at the mercy of Medium featuring and prioritizing your story
If you're publishing the same post on your site and Medium, have different titles because you can use a boxing out SEO strategy and have two chances for a reader to click on your article
Other than that, you optimize for Google SEO the same way you would on-site content—except it'll probably perform better because Medium has a higher domain rating.

text: But Medium is secretive about how they prioritize content. It's definitely based on claps and responses, but I don't know if they scrape text or whatever to diversify their featured stories or whatever. I read somewhere that they have featured editors that hand select the stories, but I don't see how that can be true if there's so many new articles a day.

elements.text: But Medium is secretive about how they prioritize content.
